Idk what med school you worked at, but I would not say that[.] representative at all. im sorry your experience was poor enough that you formed such sweeping generalizations about a group of people. 

Large urban state school mid-level in terms of ranking. I don't regret working there at all. Gave me an insight into life sciences most software people don't get. It wasn't a poor experience. People are people.

Also, we generalize all the time. There is no avoiding it. You just have to put that aside and treat individuals as individuals.

mine lectures humanities, empathy, gender, race, and all manors or critical thinking ad nauseum.

Med school humanities and humanities humanities are two very different things. A typical pre-med college student just isn't going to have the same experience as a theater major. I have engineering degrees. We have the same problem.

Medical education and medicine as a whole has all kinds of problems. It is not a positive environment. It does not make people better human beings. It is also this way for all kinds of reasons and there is no easy way to change it.  In the end you still need to go to the doctor when you are sick. Probably the most gratitude I have ever felt was being sick and having a doctor available to treat me.

Life is not perfect or pretty. I don't think that anyone is served by pretending that it is.
